Mason v. Coleman directly interprets and applies G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a removal context and repeatedly reaffirms that the operative standard is the “best interests of the child,” consistent with the broader § 28 best‑interests framework and with Schuler. Thus, using Mason alongside § 28 and Schuler as authority for a best‑interests standard in custody/relocation modifications is accurate and supported by the opinion’s holding and reasoning.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The proposition is simply a string cite to G.L. c. 208, § 28, Mason v. Coleman, and Schuler v. Schuler, without specifying a discrete rule; in this context Schuler is commonly cited for the standard governing modification of child support/alimony under § 28. This opinion squarely discusses § 28 and holds that modification requires a material change in circumstances and that the judge must weigh all relevant circumstances, including needs of the children and financial status of the provider. Thus it provides direct authority consistent with the usual legal proposition for which it is cited alongside § 28 and Mason.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. Buchanan v. Buchanan, 353 Mass. 351, 352 (1967). An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1976, c. 279, § 1. Whitney v. Whitney, 325 Mass. 28, 31 (1949). The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”
